caption: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going on seven years now. I was functioning until I lost my apartment, then my job. I was living with this one couple for a while but they kicked me out. But I try not to think about how long it‚Äôs been. I‚Äôve read books about heroin addicts who changed their lives around twenty-six, so you know. I‚Äôm still young. I just want to get back to my life. I‚Äôm tired of waking up and needing it to not feel sick. I‚Äôm tired of being homeless. I want to start talking to my family again; that‚Äôs the biggest, I think. The not speaking to my parents. I missed my mom‚Äôs birthday. And my sister‚Äôs birthday; just two days ago. I really am blessed with a good family. I mean, my parents were strict; but I can‚Äôt blame that anymore. I‚Äôve been trying to figure out the source of it. I think part of me just wanted to try everything. You know: what‚Äôs it like? But I think there was another part of me that wanted the attention, I guess. Something I could do so that people would like, ask me: are you ok? Some way to share the pain. I tried to kill myself once, when I was fourteen. I don‚Äôt know; I had such a good life. I was just so mad at myself for being so sad.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúMy mom was a witch. Now she‚Äôs a Norse Pagan. I think she just finds the whitest religion she can possibly believe in. It‚Äôs like: alright Carol, do your thing. I‚Äôm here to support you. Then I have an edgelord older brother, who‚Äôs all: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm a Satanist.‚Äô OK, Andrew. Let‚Äôs calm down. My dad is more of a Mexican Catholic Guy. He just copes. He‚Äôs really banking on the whole last rites thing, so he‚Äôs kinda sorted. Honestly, I wish I was religious. At least they have something. Because for me it‚Äôs like: ‚ÄòOh shit, there‚Äôs nothing next.‚Äô And that doesn‚Äôt sound nice. But ultimately life is just a series of chemical reactions, which is a depressing way of thinking about it. But I mean, I‚Äôm pretty sure that‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening here. Even these thoughts‚Äîthey‚Äôre just a series of chemical reactions, and one day the reactions end, and you can‚Äôt think anymore. I don‚Äôt even want to think about it. My therapist was like: ‚ÄòYou should really stop thinking about it.‚Äô I‚Äôve actually chilled out a lot from when I was at my worst. Here‚Äôs something I use to comfort myself: ultimately my body is going to decay and I‚Äôll get recycled back into the earth, right? And maybe a mushroom will spring up from my body. That‚Äôs a new form of something-or-other. And when the Earth finally comes to an end‚Äî my molecules will still be there, in some form. Just floating through the universe, forever. So that‚Äôs nice, I guess. That‚Äôs a comforting thought.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúHe was more than my brother; he was my best friend. I wanted to be him. He was more athletic, had more friends, got more girls. And things were going great for him. He was managing a pizza place. He had two kids, my nephews. But after he lost his job he started dealing drugs. He didn‚Äôt last two months in the streets. Benjamin thought the world was like our family; he was too trusting of people. And Detroit is a very dangerous place to be trusting of people. The Detroit Police Department did nothing: no leads, no investigation. It‚Äôs like he wasn‚Äôt even human. You can just murder people in that city. After his death I forgot about school. I dropped my classes, started drinking more, partying more. There was a lot of sex, a lot of meaningless sex. Nothing seemed to matter. It was dark. I was so angry at God, because how could he let that happen? But it‚Äôs been four years now. And looking back‚Äîif he hadn‚Äôt been killed, so many other things don‚Äôt happen. I‚Äôd have never left Detroit. Benjamin was the one who always told me: ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre special. You don‚Äôt have to stay here.‚Äô But if he hadn‚Äôt been killed, I‚Äôd have never come to New York. And if I don‚Äôt come to New York, I don‚Äôt meet my best friend, which is my wife. Our wedding brought my whole family together for the first time since Benjamin‚Äôs death. It was love and joy again. My mom walking me down the aisle, after losing her son. It just meant the world to her. And if I hadn‚Äôt met my wife, we wouldn‚Äôt have a son on the way. We‚Äôre naming him Benjamin.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúFinding time for them, that‚Äôs the hardest part. For my Autistic son especially; because he‚Äôs the one that needs me the most. I work full time. But I feel like they only get to see the strict mom, the military mom. The school is always asking us to do more academic things with them. So it‚Äôs a lot of: let‚Äôs do homework, let‚Äôs read books. Then after that it‚Äôs: we have to eat, we have to take a shower, we have to go to bed. And let‚Äôs do it fast. Because you need to get to sleep. You need your rest, because we have so much to do tomorrow. I feel like what I‚Äôm missing most, at this moment, is fun. There‚Äôs no time for fun. caption: ‚ÄúNobody taught me. There were so many of us in the house, and even my Nanna didn‚Äôt know how to read. So I never learned to read. I was so bad at school that I acted like a clown just to avoid everything; then I got caught running around here with a pistol when I was thirteen. They sent me to Tryon Juvenile Detention Center, and that‚Äôs where I met Ms. Lakewood. She taught the computer class. Heavy-set Italian lady, about 4‚Äô 10‚Äù. But attitude, huge. Aura, big. She was like the grandmother in a mob movie. You know how you‚Äôve got all the bosses, but when the grandmother comes in‚Äîeveryone shuts up? She was like that. But she was loving too. She had pictures on the wall of all her favorite students; she called them her babies. She even had a picture of Mike Tyson up there. He was one of her babies. One day we had this contest, on the computer. The winner got $50. And I was looking at the screen and getting so angry. I‚Äôm crying, because I couldn‚Äôt read. And that‚Äôs when this Spanish kid called me Forrest Gump. He had the whole class laughing at me. Miss Lakewood was like: ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs going on?‚Äô She came over to me and said: ‚ÄòFix your face. Fix your fucking face, I don‚Äôt want to see another tear.‚Äô Then she said: ‚ÄòTomorrow, you better get ready.‚Äô She started working with me for an hour-and-a-half, every night. She started me on Lion King. It was a preschool book, so I didn‚Äôt want to do it. But she made me. Every night she made me keep reading until I was able to read on my grade level. I started getting report cards with nothing less than 85. I was sending them home; my mom was getting hyped. I got my GED. I started reading so much. Today I can finish a five-hundred-page book in two days. If I smoke a blunt first, I swear to God I can picture the whole book like it‚Äôs a movie. Miss Lakewood passed away when I was eighteen. I heard about it while I was in prison. Some new guys came in; they‚Äôd been in Tryon too. They heard me talking about her and that‚Äôs when one of them told me. But he said: ‚ÄòYo. I‚Äôm pretty sure she had your picture on the wall.‚Äô‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúI was seventeen. Only child, not a lot of friends. But I had a plan. I was going to become an actress, get a role on All My Children, meet my husband on set‚Äî and when that was all over‚ÄîI‚Äôd host a talk show. Kelly Ripa did it; I could do it too. Back then it seemed like every woman on television had gotten their start as beauty queen. So my senior year I decided to enter my school‚Äôs Homecoming Queen competition. It was organized like a Ms. America pageant. But this was a rough high school, only one other girl signed up‚Äî so I had a good shot. My whole family got behind me. My mom was a seamstress. We noticed that in most pageants we watched, the winner wore a white dress. So she sewed me a white dress that I picked out of Seventeen Magazine. First came the interview portion, and that‚Äôs when the trouble started. The judges asked me about the Anita Hill testimony; I wasn‚Äôt ready for that. I was ready for world peace. They were supposed to ask me about my goals, so I could say world peace. But that didn‚Äôt happen. The talent portion was later that night at the homecoming dance. The whole school was there. I chose a Sheena Easton song; poor choice. Not the right crowd for that. The other girl chose ‚ÄòI Feel Good‚Äô by Stephanie Mills, and she had the whole crowd singing along. That‚Äôs when I knew it was over. But then, a miracle. The guidance counselor quieted everyone down, and announced the winner: it was me. Me! It was my Kelly Kapowski moment. Everyone was cheering, the other girl congratulated me. But it only lasted five seconds, because the guidance counselor said: ‚ÄòWait a second, I‚Äôm sorry. Joanna is the runner-up.‚Äô It was the worst moment of my life. In fact, the only thing that got me through COVID was knowing that it could not possibly, possibly be worse than that moment. And here‚Äôs a twist for you. Remember that guidance counselor? Several years later I ended up acting alongside his son in a play at Queens College. In one scene I pulled a gun on him, and the director was like: ‚ÄòWe need more anger. Think about something that makes you angry.‚Äô I was like: ‚ÄòWell, that‚Äôs easy. His father ruined my senior year. And quite possibly, my entire life.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúHe was a mentor. The leader of a huge religious organization: intelligent, charismatic. Everyone respected him. I was a teenage girl. My father traveled a lot. I never had any boyfriends. I wanted affection. And for him to give me attention, it was like‚ÄîI wanted that. I did want it. I wanted him to look at me. I would dress for him. It makes me sick to think about now, but I would choose my clothes solely to make him look at me. I wanted him to say that I was pretty. I wanted his attention. And because I wanted it at first, you know‚ÄîI felt like I gave myself to this person willingly. That‚Äôs why I didn‚Äôt report it for so many years. Because I felt like I was tempting him. He waited until I turned eighteen. And every time he abused me, he encouraged me to share the responsibility. He used the word ‚Äòwe.‚Äô Always ‚Äòwe.‚Äô He‚Äôd say: ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre not supposed to be doing this. You‚Äôre making me do this. I don‚Äôt want to, but you‚Äôre making me do this.‚Äô Every time it was over, he‚Äôd say: ‚ÄòNow go to church and confess. Confess to tempting an older man.‚Äô I sued him last year, thanks to the Adult Survivors Act. I expected him to fight it tooth and nail; deny everything. But a couple days ago he sent a statement to my lawyer, basically apologizing for everything. When I got the letter, I thought of the child me. All I did in my mind was hug that child. It‚Äôs like: you can forgive yourself now. There was never any ‚Äòwe.‚Äô He knew you didn‚Äôt have a father figure. He knew how you‚Äôd respond to the attention. He knew how you‚Äôd respond to the guilt, and the shame. He knew everything. It may have felt like you were choosing, but you weren‚Äôt. You were chosen.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúOccasionally I‚Äôll have a beer after work and break out the sketchbook. But I had wanted to be this great painter. I wanted to do these grand things: big, huge oil paintings. But those days of painting all the time were such a roller coaster. There were these periods of extreme depression, followed by manic states of trying to put myself out there. I couldn‚Äôt do it anymore. I mainly felt sorry for my dad. I know it was rough for him. My mom hadn‚Äôt wanted me to go to art school. She wanted me to do something more practical, but my dad said: ‚ÄòNo. This is what he wants to do, and I want to support his dream.‚Äô And then I abandoned it. That was the first time I had to deal with real failure. A lot of times when you‚Äôre an artist‚Äîit‚Äôs your job, it‚Äôs your lifestyle, it‚Äôs your entire fucking identity. It wasn‚Äôt like I failed to do a thing. It was like: I failed to be something, you know? It was a failure to live up to what I thought was my destiny. But then on the other side of that-- there was this figuring out that there was nothing wrong with me the entire time. I didn‚Äôt need to be something else to have meaningful friendships, or a good relationship. I didn‚Äôt need to be something else to be loved and cared about. After work tonight I‚Äôm going to meet up with a person who‚Äôs in love with me, and I can‚Äôt wait. And that person met me long after I gave up on being a full-time artist. They met me when I wasn‚Äôt even a chef yet. I was a piss-poor, part-time line cook. But even then-- they decided I was worth it. So you know, there‚Äôs something there. caption: ‚ÄúJust the other day a video popped up on Facebook. It was only five years ago. We were in the park. I was pushing her on the bike, letting go. We used to have so much fun together. We‚Äôd always get ice cream. She‚Äôs a strawberry girl. I‚Äôm a vanilla guy. Chipwich, actually. I‚Äôm a Chipwich guy. She‚Äôd give me a hug afterward, tell me I was the best dad ever. We were such good friends. But now it feels like we‚Äôre so far apart. She doesn‚Äôt want to talk to me anymore. Even when she‚Äôs upset, she‚Äôll ignore me and go to her room. It‚Äôs like: C‚Äômon. I was fifteen too. I know what it‚Äôs like. But she‚Äôll come back, I know that. They always come back. But it does feels like you‚Äôre getting your heart ripped out a little bit.  But look, I get it. She‚Äôs figuring out life. You have to back off. You have to give them space. Cause if you charge after them and get all aggressive about it, you might push them away forever. But they always come back, right? One day she‚Äôs gonna realize that I‚Äôm not the enemy and I‚Äôm really her dad, her friend. I still get a flicker of it, every once in awhile. We had a really surreal moment last year. Her birthday is March 17th. She‚Äôs a St. Paddy‚Äôs Day birthday. We always take her to a Spanish restaurant on Long Island, but this time we did something special. Her uncle used to be a bodyguard for Taylor Swift, and we still know some people at the company. So they got us tickets to her concert. Fifth row seats. I mean, don‚Äôt get me wrong. We paid for them-- but fifth row center. She was crying. I got a big hug. A big kiss. A ‚ÄòThank you, Dad.‚Äô It wasn‚Äôt ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre the best dad ever.‚Äô But it was a really big: ‚ÄòThank you, Dad.‚Äô‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúPeople see it as a fake sport. Whenever you tell someone you play Ultimate, it‚Äôs like: oh, is that where you throw a frisbee in a basket? Or is that the one where you throw it to a dog? Whenever I‚Äôm talking to someone about it, I just hope they‚Äôll ask me enough questions so that I can talk about UNC Ultimate. That was probably the most special experience I‚Äôm ever going to have in my whole life. I was on the team for five years, then I came back and coached. My freshman year we were really, really bad. But at the moment UNC Chapel Hill is triple back-to-back-to-back national champions. And I got to be part of that trajectory. But even though the team kept getting better and better, I kinda stayed at the same level. I never became the elite player that I wanted to be. I have a lot of ‚Äòstick-to-it-ive-ness.‚Äô I‚Äôm capable of working really, really hard. And part of me always believed that would be enough, which is the part that burned me out. Because after working so hard, for so long, I reached a plateau. It was physical stuff. I‚Äôm just not quick enough. When I play defense I can‚Äôt keep up with the fastest offensive handlers. They‚Äôre going to score, and that‚Äôs a problem. I ended up getting cut from the elite women‚Äôs club team I was on. I switched over to mixed, but ended up tearing my ACL a couple years ago. It‚Äôs been my life for ten years, but now I‚Äôm at a place where I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôm ever going to play again. I just don‚Äôt know if my body can handle it. I don‚Äôt want to have another, like massive orthopedic surgery. And frisbee takes up so much bandwidth; there‚Äôs so many other things I want to explore. The list is infinitely long. I‚Äôm asking myself: could I be happy playing on a mid-level team where the commitment wouldn‚Äôt be quite as high? Or will I only feel satisfied if I‚Äôm exceptional? That‚Äôs an unhealthy connection I have in my head, I think. That love is something you need to earn. And being exceptional will make me worthy of having connections with people. It would be great to become a version of myself where I no longer feel that way. And maybe we‚Äôll get there someday. We‚Äôre working on it. In the meantime, at least I got to talk about UNC Ultimate.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúMy first end-of-life patient was a 97-year-old man. He had a much younger girlfriend; she was seventy-four. But they loved each other so much. Back when their spouses were still alive, the four of them had been great friends. They would double date together. And when their spouses passed away‚Äîthe two of them became a thing. Every day she would come over for lunch. I‚Äôd always cook a little meal for them. I‚Äôd prepare the table; I‚Äôd lay out my little candles and my little flowers. As soon as she arrived I‚Äôd put on music and dim the lights, then I‚Äôd leave the room and go wait in the bedroom. They would cuddle and snuggle. And the beauty of it was‚Äîeven though he couldn‚Äôt control his fluids at that point, she never minded the smell. Her love for him was so great that they would still kiss and all that good stuff. When the doctors said that it was time for him to go to hospice, he said he didn‚Äôt want to go. He told them that he wanted to come back home and die with me. I was with him in the end. My patients never die alone. Never, ever. One week after his passing I was hired by his girlfriend‚Äôs family. She had terminal Alzheimer‚Äôs, and I ended up staying with her for seven years. I fell in love with her. We were family, just family. She used to be a tap dancer. We‚Äôd sing together. And if she didn‚Äôt feel like singing, I‚Äôd sing. Even near the end, she always knew when something was wrong with me. When I wasn‚Äôt being the Gabby that she knew-- she would always know. When the doctors said it was time for her to go to hospice, her children said: ‚ÄòWe want her to die with Gabby.‚Äô In the final days she wouldn‚Äôt eat, she‚Äôd lock her jaw. But she would always eat for me. One night I could see the fright in her eyes, and I knew it was time. My patients never die alone. Never, ever. So I climbed under the covers with her. And she passed away in my arms.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúThey told me they loved me constantly, chronically, every day. They gave me a good home. They cared for me. They did all the basics, and above all that: they worked hard to put me in a great school district. But no matter how much they provide, your parents can‚Äôt give a shit for you. I made every bad choice a high schooler could make: tv, video games, pornography. All the stuff that you use to not think about stuff. It‚Äôs immediately gratifying, maybe the first 50 or 100 times. But after the 200th time, that stuff becomes who you are. I guess the whole time I was just hoping that someone would come along and tell me exactly what to do with my life, or else it would just come to me. Maybe that happens for some people. But for the other ninety percent of us, we have to make the conscious decision to just go. At first I told my dad I was joining The Marines. He‚Äôs an attorney. It certainly wasn‚Äôt what he would have chosen for me. But he said: ‚ÄòIf this is what you want to do, you‚Äôre going to visit every branch. You‚Äôre going to make an educated decision.‚Äô On the day I signed with the Coast Guard, I remember telling him: ‚ÄòI just want to be a good man.‚Äô That‚Äôs as far as I‚Äôd gotten. That‚Äôs the only thing I knew for sure. I didn‚Äôt know where the path was going to lead, but I was just tired of not trying. I figured it was better to just start walking and see what the hell happens. Because I know what happens if I don‚Äôt do anything.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a tough morning for me. I used to be a children‚Äôs librarian. But this morning I had to call publishers and tell them not to send me any more books. I just can‚Äôt read them anymore, not like I used to. And that was hard. It felt like I was cutting off a lifeline. It‚Äôs disappointing, the sense of not being in control of my own life anymore. Everything depends on my medical schedule, and the chemotherapy, and what my limits are. The doctor has told me to expect a couple more years, but my caretaker says she‚Äôs seen a lot of sick people. And she thinks I could be one of the ones who can beat it. For most of my life happiness was automatic. I might have had the only career where you get told ‚ÄòI love you‚Äô three or four times a week. Maybe it happens with teachers too, but so many little kids said those words to me over the years. And I miss that. I was damned lucky to have that experience. Happiness isn‚Äôt automatic anymore, these days I have to work a little bit more for it. In addition to all the pain and the fear and having to pee all the time, I choose to do a lot of things that will make me aware of the beauty and loveliness of life. It's not magic. I don‚Äôt stop thinking about the scary stuff, I just find moments to push them aside with the ridiculous. There‚Äôs so much in life that‚Äôs ridiculous. Every Saturday morning I watch Popeye on Turner Classic Movies. It‚Äôs so ridiculous. Olive Oil is so obnoxious. And you know, she has all these men after her. It‚Äôs just really funny. And Popeye is so full of himself and somehow manages to come out of everything, eat his spinach, and win. Then there‚Äôs my laughing yoga classes, which I can‚Äôt do in person anymore. But I do them online. There‚Äôs this thing we do where people will get in lines of three or four, and we‚Äôll pretend to have a boat race. Everyone rows as hard as they can. Someone chooses a winner, and if you lose you get to create a big scene and make an ass of yourself. It‚Äôs ridiculous. And then there‚Äôs you. You‚Äôre ridiculous. You‚Äôre stopping random people, presumably to entertain yourself. You‚Äôre sitting in the middle of the street. I mean, think about it. It‚Äôs pretty dumb.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúI grew up with strangers. I wasn‚Äôt even with my parents from first to fifth grade. All the people that were supposed to care for me, and teach me, and guide me, they all failed me. It caused a lot of anger and honestly, a lot of heartbreak. I even wondered if my family was cursed. Like all we do is come into this world and we struggle. From the age of twelve I had to go straight home from school and take care of my baby sister. I was the one making sure she was OK: feeding her, changing her, bathing her. It‚Äôs like my life was in shackles. I didn‚Äôt even start playing basketball for real until I was sixteen. That was the summer I was like: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm done. I‚Äôm not y‚Äôall‚Äôs babysitter.‚Äô I started waking up early and going to the park for hours, doing drills. Basketball gave me a sense of control. The more I worked, the better I got, and it was like: ‚ÄòWow. I can really do this.‚Äô It‚Äôs like I was finally the one writing my story. I ended up trying out for the school team my senior year: no skills, no talent, just starting to understand the game. But the things I could do, I did better than everyone else: diving for loose balls, grabbing rebounds, and hustling. It was mainly hustle. And I think the coach saw that, or maybe he just felt sorry for me. Because he created an extra spot on the roster just for me. There weren‚Äôt even enough uniforms, I had a different uniform than everybody else, and during the away games the crowd would let me know. They let me hear it, but I didn‚Äôt care. I was just so happy to be there. I couldn‚Äôt shoot, but I‚Äôd go one hundred percent on defense. The coach would put me on the other team‚Äôs best player. I‚Äôd stay right up under his jersey. I‚Äôd chase him all over the court. And by the end of the year I was in the rotation. We won the city championship that year. During the final game our starters got off to a slow start, and the coach wanted some energy. So he looked down to the end of the bench and said: ‚ÄòRey, go in.‚Äô Right away I got a steal. The crowd was going wild. Proudest moment of my life. I took it all the way back down the court, and unfortunately, I missed the lay-up. Would have been a perfect ending, but man. I was just way too excited.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúThe person who hurt us, hurt both of us. But it affected us differently. I isolated myself. I started taking drugs when I was twelve, maybe thirteen. But she just moved on with her life. I could never understand: how can she be so happy, while I‚Äôm stuck in my head and constantly thinking about it? It was exhausting to me. She was exhausting to me, especially when we were teenagers. I couldn‚Äôt stand to be around her because she was so light and positive and funny. Everything was always so cool, and so good. It felt to me that she didn‚Äôt want to face it. She just wanted to accept that it happened, and move on. But I couldn‚Äôt move on. I didn‚Äôt have that choice. I couldn‚Äôt just choose to not think about it. I remember the bad things, and how they made me feel. And I never want to feel that way again. I couldn‚Äôt just go back out into the world like it never even happened. I know that there are a lot more good people than bad, I do believe that. But there are bad people too. And they can really hurt you deeply if you give them your trust. So I never trusted anyone. Three years ago it reached a point where I felt completely hopeless. It was all so exhausting. I was exhausted. Exhausted from carrying these heavy feelings. Exhausted from making bad decisions. Exhausted from the drugs. It felt like nothing was ever going to change for me. Around that time we went out to dinner with my mother, and we finally had a deep talk about everything. We‚Äôd talked about it before, but maybe this time I really meant it. I decided that I have to let it go. I just have to let it go. I still have dark times when I don‚Äôt want to study or work. But when I‚Äôm in a bad mood, I‚Äôll turn to her. Her happiness doesn‚Äôt make me feel worse anymore. It motivates me. It inspires me. Now she‚Äôs the person who can most easily put me in a good mood. I let her be a part of my bad days. And because of that, she‚Äôs also become a huge part of my good days. Both of us have gotten a lot more mature, and a lot wiser. But it was mainly me, I think. I had to change. If I hadn‚Äôt found a way to let go, we‚Äôd still be too different to be this close.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been doing good work lately. My schoolwork, I mean. God that sounds so nerdy. But this year I‚Äôve been trying to make school less about the grade and more about doing work that makes me proud. To put it bluntly, I wrote some good fucking essays this year. There‚Äôs this one paper called The Term Paper. Every junior has to do it. It‚Äôs six to eight pages. Just say the words ‚ÄòThe Term Paper‚Äô to a sophomore, and they will cower in fear. It‚Äôs supposed to be the culmination of everything you‚Äôve learned about literature. Everyone begins by making their proposal to the teacher. The coolest thing about essays, as opposed to say math, is that they‚Äôre one of the only chances you get in high school to say something original. So I was like: ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs go, let‚Äôs push it.‚Äô We were supposed to choose one book. But I told my teacher: ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs an author I love named Kazuo Ishiguro, and I‚Äôd like to compare two of his books.‚Äô She told me nobody had ever asked that before, but she let me do it. And for the longest time it seemed like I‚Äôd made a huge mistake. It took me six months. It was such a complicated argument, it took me almost twenty pages. I felt so tired. I had no idea if I was going to finish on time. Even with an extension, I turned it in fifteen minutes before the deadline. But when she gave me the paper back, she said something I couldn‚Äôt believe. She said: ‚ÄòThis is graduate level work.‚Äô It was the proudest moment of my life. It‚Äôs only been sixteen years, but still. Writing was never my strength. I think back to my crappy little paragraphs about ‚ÄòTo Kill A Mockingbird‚Äô that I wrote in seventh grade. Even in eighth and ninth grade, my essays were still pretty shit. But I started really working hard to make them better. And I just kinda kept working. And it wasn‚Äôt just six months that went into that paper. It was those six years of getting better. And I don‚Äôt know if it will get published or anything, that‚Äôs probably not something I can do. But for her to say that, it means my work is getting close to what people are actually doing out there in the world. I‚Äôm not sure if this makes sense. But it made me feel like I‚Äôm finally part of the world. Instead of just in it.‚Äù

caption: (53/54) ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a beautiful word in itself, Mitra. Someone who has no idea of its meaning can appreciate its beauty. Mitra always had a genius for beauty. She knew it completely. She wanted it around her at all times. Even now she keeps a book of Hafez by our bedside. It‚Äôs always in reach, and whenever she finds a verse that she loves, she will bring it to me. She still trusts me to find the melody. Poetry is one of the things that she still remembers best. Because poetry is music. It sinks into the memory. Even if you can‚Äôt remember a word, the rhythm will guide you. The rhyme will give you a hint. Recently we were reciting a poem from an old book, and one of the words had completely faded. It was a poem that we both used to love. And I was so mad at myself. I kept trying to remember the word, but it would not come to me. Then suddenly she said it. It made me so happy. It doesn‚Äôt hurt when she forgets anymore, but it makes me so happy when she remembers. To know that the memory is still inside of her. That she is still holding on. Our lives are just a fistful of memories, ice melting in our hands. And Mitra‚Äôs ice is melting faster than mine. But she still has more memories of me than anyone else. And I have a lifetime of memories every time I look at her. And until the last moment, until the last ice has melted, we will still be us. Our entire lives we‚Äôve been on two different roads. But the horizon was always the same. It was an unwritten promise: that no matter what happens, I will keep you. Even when we disagree, I will keep you. From a distance, I will keep you. In the dark, I will keep you. In the deepest pit, I will keep you. Even if you lose your country, even if you lose your eye, even if you lose your memory, I will keep you. We will still be us. It‚Äôs the only thing we ever agreed on. We always agreed on us. It‚Äôs one of the earliest principles of Iran. It‚Äôs where she gets her name. Mitra, the God of Promises.‚Äù

caption:
I want to begin by thanking Parviz Zafari. Though it seems strange to say his name, because I‚Äôve only ever heard him called Bubjan, which means Grandfather. When I met Bubjan I only intended his story to be a single post. But as his life began to unspool before me, putting his soul and wisdom into a story became a mission for me. I‚Äôve never met a man who so lived what he believed. You‚Äôve been a great teacher to me, Bubjan. Thank you for showing me that truth is something you do. ‚Äâ
‚Äâ
Thank you to my close friend @rostamzafari. It was his devotion to his grandfather that sparked all of this. I joke that he dragged me into his house and sat me at Bubjan‚Äôs feet. Rostam would also serve as interpreter for all 100 hours of interviews. Rostam is one of the most brilliant, talented, and ethical people I‚Äôve ever met. He is very much like his grandfather, only he took his love of Shahnameh a step further by tattooing scenes from the book all over his body. ‚Äâ
‚Äâ
I want to thank the entire Zafari family: every member played a part in this. Mitra, you are the sun. Thanks to Sepanta Mohseni for holding us together. Thank you to Dr. Maziar Zafari, who I call ‚ÄòThe General.‚Äô He was a chief advisor to the whole project and ripped my drafts to shreds until all the history was correct. We locked horns a few times, but we are better friends because of it. And the story is certainly better because of it.‚Äâ
‚Äâ
Thank you to Azadeh Vatanpour and Rashid Fani, for creating a translation so good that it was often referred to as the ‚Äòoriginal Farsi version.‚Äô (With an assist from Dr. Zafari.) Thank you to my agent Brian DeFiore, first and last fingerprints on all my stories. Thank you to my beautiful wife Erin, for loving me despite my obsessions. Thank you to everyone who supports Humans of New York on Patreon‚Äîyou are the reason I have the space and time to do this work. ‚Äâ
‚Äâ
Thank you to the God of Soul and Wisdom, as God is called in this story. Do the next good thing, a way appears. Thank you to Mahsa Jina Amini and the women of Iran, you continue to inspire us. ‚Äâ
And lastly, thanks to all of you who read these stories. Sharing them continues to be the great privilege and joy of my life.

caption: (50/54) ‚ÄúWhen I was eighty I was giving an interview on Persian television. I wanted to recite a verse, from the part of Shahnameh when Rostam selects Rakhsh as his horse. But no matter how hard I tried, I could not remember the line. For almost a minute I sat still. After that I stopped giving speeches. I‚Äôm at a new stage now. I‚Äôve accepted this. It‚Äôs like an arrow that‚Äôs descending. It‚Äôs been a long flight. But it‚Äôs nearly reached its destination. I‚Äôve done all I can. So now I try to think through the soul of our people. It‚Äôs in the hands of the young people now. They‚Äôre the ones with energy. They‚Äôre the ones that can change the regime. In the great battles of Shahnameh, as long as the flag is flying high‚Äîthe army remains strong. The flag must stay raised. When the flag falls, the battle is lost. The flag of this regime is the hijab. For as long as I can remember. For my entire life, it‚Äôs the thing they‚Äôve cared about most. It‚Äôs something that can be visualized. Something that can be seen from afar. No matter how low they sink, no matter how weak they are, it‚Äôs the one proof that they‚Äôre still in control. That they still control half of Iran. They‚Äôve made it their flag. But their castle is surrounded. The flag is falling fast. And when it finally hits the ground, the regime will end. Mitra and I do whatever we can to support. We go to the protests.  She wears her ‚ÄòWoman, Life, Freedom‚Äô hat. She doesn‚Äôt remember the exact dates, or the exact events. But she can feel it in the air. She knows something‚Äôs coming. She brought home two Mahsa Jina Amini T-shirts from one of the protests. She hung one in our living room, and the other in our bedroom. I can not fight it, her word is law. Lately she has become obsessed with the idea of going back to Iran. She thinks we‚Äôre going home. She‚Äôs always saying: Where are we going to live? Who are we going to see? It‚Äôs not a delusion. The hope is inside her. And is inside of me too. I still hope that I will live to see it. The new Iran. Just a glimpse would be enough for me. As Ferdowsi writes: ‚ÄòEven a few drops sipped at the end of evil, is worth more than all the years of life.‚Äù

caption: (49/54) ‚ÄúWe still take long walks together, even today. There‚Äôs a path through the forest near our house. Mitra still can‚Äôt stand the silence. She‚Äôll walk off the path so she can hear the dry crunch of the leaves. She still talks the entire time, but these days our conversations don‚Äôt reach back as far as they used to. We mainly talk about the things we see. She‚Äôll count her steps, count the houses, count the trees. Mitra‚Äôs memory is no longer her friend; it no longer supports her. But she still says ‚Äòhello‚Äô to everyone that she sees. And she‚Äôs still a queen, I am always at her service. These days we have become inseparable. If I do not see her for two minutes, I will find what room she‚Äôs in. I button her jacket. I tie her shoes. I handle all her medications. I do not grieve the situation. I feel gratitude that I am able to do these things for her, despite nature. My only grief is for her. Her memory was her greatest gift. It‚Äôs where I stored my treasures. I could tell her any verse, even once. And she could remember it forever. Now it will escape her after only a minute. Every day her world gets smaller and smaller. Tighter and tighter. It‚Äôs the oldest memories that she remembers most now. Recently she has been fixated on her hand. She keeps holding up her crippled hand, and asking: ‚ÄòWhy did you ever marry me?‚Äô When we were young in Tehran, her father had a tradition. Every morning he would insist on having the first cup of tea. He said it was the one that tasted best. He called it ‚Äòthe flower of the tea.‚Äô So now when I brew our tea every morning, I will wait. Until Mitra is up. Until she‚Äôs ready. So that I can serve her the flower of the tea. Then as soon as we‚Äôve finished the kettle, she‚Äôll make me go outside. And pour the remains on the roots of our trees.‚Äù
alt: Photo by Humans of New York on September 15, 2023.

caption: (48/54) ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt raise them to be Iranian first. Above all I wanted them to be good people. I wanted the same things for them that I want for all people: to do the next right thing, to say the next true thing. But they were growing up in tough times. So many bad things were being done in the name of Iranians. I wanted them to know the real Iran. I wasn‚Äôt able to bring them there, but I did try to build a little Iran around us. I‚Äôve surrounded us with my memories of home. On the wall hangs a painting of Nahavand that I made in Germany. Above the back door hangs the horns of the first ibex I ever hunted. On the shelf in the dining room is my jar of soil. It was collected from a spot in Nahavand at the base of the mountain, right at the source of the spring. And next to my jar of soil, for anyone who needs it: sits my Shahnameh. As soon as they were old enough I asked each of them to memorize a verse about their namesake. Zaal went first. His namesake was one of the wisest heroes in all of Shahnameh: ùò°ùò¢ùò¢ùò≠ ùò¨ùòØùò¶ùò∏ ùò¢ùò≠ùò≠ ùòµùò©ùò™ùòØùò®ùò¥ ùò®ùò≥ùò¶ùò¢ùòµ ùò¢ùòØùò• ùò¥ùòÆùò¢ùò≠ùò≠, ùòØùò¶ùò¢ùò≥ ùò¢ùòØùò• ùòßùò¢ùò≥. ùòèùò™ùò¥ ùò∏ùò™ùò¥ùò•ùò∞ùòÆ ùò¥ùò©ùò∞ùòØùò¶ ùò¢ùò¥ ùò™ùòß ùò¢ ùò¥ùòµùò¢ùò≥. Rostam went next. He chose from a part of Shahnameh when Iran finds itself in a moment of great darkness. Three enemy kings have aligned their forces. Three hundred thousand men march against us. The army is on the brink of defeat. The dirt‚Äôs turned clay with blood. Rostam arrives at the battlefield on foot: no horse, no armor, carrying nothing but a bow and arrow. He walks out to face the enemy alone. And with a single shot, he slays the greatest champion on the other side. The enemy is stunned into silence. Their courage flees them. Their commander screams: ùòûùò©ùò∞ ùò¢ùò≥ùò¶ ùòµùò©ùò¶ùò¥ùò¶ ùòóùò¶ùò≥ùò¥ùò™ùò¢ùòØùò¥? ùòïùò∞ùòµ ùò¶ùò∑ùò¶ùòØ ùò¢ ùò≠ùò™ùò∞ùòØ ùò§ùò∞ùò∂ùò≠ùò• ùò¥ùòµùò¢ùòØùò• ùò¢ùò®ùò¢ùò™ùòØùò¥ùòµ ùòµùò©ùò¶ùòÆ! It‚Äôs one of my favorite verses in all of Shahnameh. My entire life, ever since I was a little boy, those have always been my favorite scenes. The ones that make me most emotional. The ones that make my voice break. When at the moment of greatest darkness, one champion makes a stand. And with a single act of courage reveals the soul of an entire people.‚Äù

caption: (51/54) ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs coming. In the streets it is silent. But in the homes, where Iran still lives, the drumbeat is building. The anger is building. The impatience is building, and soon it will come out. Iran will come out. Our young women have been leading us. But we cannot let them march one-by-one into the night. Do not pass by silently if a woman is getting harassed in the street. Do not let them be called whores or sluts. Speak! Say this is not right! Your neighbor will hear you, and they will say it too. Until all of us are saying it together. The only way to take the battlefield is together. Those of us in free societies, with the freedom to speak, and write, and protest. Do not sit behind the walls of your castle. Write. Speak. Protest. We don‚Äôt need the same chants, or the same slogans.  But let us come together. Even if it‚Äôs only around our dining room tables, let us come together. We cannot let them face the enemy alone. In Iran they are standing up: the students of Tehran, the truck drivers of Bandar Abbas, the oil workers of Khuzestan, the factory workers of Pooladshahr, the teachers of Sanandaj, the farmers of Isfahan. Everyone has found their own way of saying: ‚ÄòThis does not work for us.‚Äô Everyone is choosing their own words, but now let us say them all together. If you can‚Äôt find the courage to march in the streets, then just open your doors. Stand on your stoop as the protesters pass. That would be enough. If everyone who is against this regime could only do that, we‚Äôd fill all of Iran. It will be the end. These enforcers will realize that there is no one with them. Because those policeman, those soldiers, they‚Äôre also the people. Iran lives inside of them too. There is only one battle left. The fight against fear. When we win against the fear in our hearts, we win Iran. And in the words of Ferdowsi: ‚ÄòWithout fighting, they will flee the scene.‚Äô‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúGrowing up I was very much in my own head, my own world. Instead of getting a babysitter my mom would just go to work and leave me at the house. We didn‚Äôt have a TV or anything. And when there‚Äôs no one to talk to, you just become your own friend. I‚Äôd look out the window and try to imagine myself doing things. Like: ‚ÄòWhat would it be like if I was standing on that roof? What sort of things would I see?‚Äô But when you do that too much, at some point you get lost. I didn‚Äôt even feel alone. It‚Äôs hard to explain, because I haven‚Äôt experienced nothing else. But it's like: you don‚Äôt feel lonely if there‚Äôs never nobody else there. And there was never nobody else there. Alone was my normal. It was my comfortable. So when we first started dating, I didn‚Äôt know what to do. Every time we were alone I would speak non-stop. Then I‚Äôd stop myself mid-sentence and be like, ‚ÄòDamn. I‚Äôm speaking a lot. I need to shut up.‚Äô And she‚Äôd be like: ‚ÄòNo, just keep telling me what you were telling me.‚Äô I was just so excited. I felt like l a kid with a new toy. I‚Äôm not calling her a toy, that‚Äôs not what I mean. But that‚Äôs how I felt. Like I don‚Äôt know how this works, but I can‚Äôt believe I have it. I‚Äôm in love now. For so long I‚Äôd told myself: ‚ÄòThis is never going to happen.‚Äô But then it actually happened. It was like: ‚ÄòWhat do I do? Where do I go now?‚Äô Every day has been something new. Monday feels like Saturday, because every day has meaning. I‚Äôm figuring out about her, and about myself, and about the world. Like‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt know you could have fun in winter. There‚Äôs so many indoor activities you can do, just simple things. Like wearing matching pajamas on New Years. I never knew about that stuff. It can be so fulfilling. Sometimes you don‚Äôt even have to do anything. Just having somebody sitting next to you makes you feel nice inside. And that‚Äôs how it is now. That‚Äôs how my life is. She‚Äôs my comfortable. When she‚Äôs not with me, I wish that she was. I feel what it feels to be alone.‚Äù

caption: (46/54) ‚ÄúThere was nothing I could do. It was like watching a child fall from the roof of a building. I could only look on in agony. When I arrived in Germany there were two million unemployed. It was years before I could find a job. Resistance takes resources: you must travel, you must speak, you must organize. I just didn‚Äôt have the means. I moved into a small apartment with my daughter Ahang, who was already studying in Germany. I‚Äôd spend all day listening to the radio for news reports about Iran. I kept hoping that it would be over in an instant. That a dam would break, and everyone would say at the same time: ‚ÄòThis is not working for us.‚Äô But that moment never came. The grief would not leave me. I wrote poems about Iran. I taught myself to paint, and I painted paintings of Iran. All day I‚Äôd pace back and forth in the living room. I‚Äôd talk to myself like a madman: ‚ÄòHow did we fall into this deep pit? How can we get out again?‚Äô I can‚Äôt explain it. It‚Äôs an irrational love, an illogical love. I don‚Äôt know where it comes from. It begins before my memory. There‚Äôs so much to love about Iran. It‚Äôs so many things: it‚Äôs a land, it‚Äôs a people, it‚Äôs a culture, it‚Äôs a story, it‚Äôs a myth. But it‚Äôs not something you can hold. Through it all, my greatest grief was for Mitra. Less than a month after I left the country, another war started. Iraq invaded Iran, and the borders were closed for four years. Four years without seeing her. She‚Äôd write me letters every day. She‚Äôd tell me every little thing. One year she sent me a calendar, and she‚Äôd written me a love poem from a different poet on every page. Telephones were tough to come by, but she always found a way to call. Mostly we would share news. But we still found time to read each other poetry. It is said that at any given time there are one hundred thousand poets in Iran, and I am not one of them. But in Germany I finally wrote her some poetry of my own: ‚ÄòI wish destiny didn‚Äôt demand distance / I wish you were here /Your gentle hand caressing my face /Without you, I‚Äôm a broken branch / a body without a soul/ a dying flame/ Without you, I‚Äôm Rostam with hands bound.‚Äù

caption: (52/54) ‚ÄúIt always sits out on the shelf. It‚Äôs given structure to my life. I‚Äôve wanted to be a knight. I‚Äôve wanted to be a king. I‚Äôve wanted to be Ferdowsi, living for higher ideals. But there‚Äôs old men in Shahnameh too. And that‚Äôs my idea of a king now‚Äîa grandfather. A ùòâùò∂ùò£ùò´ùò¢ùòØ. He‚Äôs more of a cultural figure. He advises his grandchildren. He keeps them together. But he doesn‚Äôt participate in their issues, regardless of how they behave. He‚Äôs like a book. He‚Äôs full of wisdom. He's there if you need him, but he doesn‚Äôt exert power over you. I‚Äôm reading it through one last time, with all eight of my grandchildren. It‚Äôs a deeper understanding now. To dive deep requires a philosopher‚Äôs tenacity, but the pearls are in the depths of the seas. These days I skim over the battle scenes. I read more diligently the parts that tell of universal values like love and kindness. The parts that are true for everyone. One of my favorite stories never made it into Shahnameh. It was passed down through our oral traditions. Iran is in the midst of the longest war it has ever fought. The fighting has gone on for more than a century. Many kings have died, both sides are exhausted, and a truce is proposed. A single champion from the Iranian side is selected. His name is Arash, ‚ÄòThe Archer.‚Äô He‚Äôs told to climb one of the highest mountains in Iran, and to shoot his arrow as far as he‚Äôs able. And wherever it lands, that will be the border of the new Iran. He climbs to the mountain‚Äôs peak. He pulls back his bow as far as he can, and he lets the arrow fly. It sails across the entire country. And sticks into a walnut tree‚Äîexactly where the previous border was before. Before the fighting, before the bloodshed. And that‚Äôs the new Iran. But Arash never gets to see it. He put his entire soul into the arrow. All of his ùòëùò¢ùò¢ùòØ. And the moment it‚Äôs released, he falls over and dies.‚Äù

caption: (47/54) ‚ÄúWhen our grandchildren were born we moved to America to help raise them. First came Ahang‚Äôs son Sepanta. Then when I turned sixty we moved into Maziar‚Äôs house to help raise his newborn twin boys. And that‚Äôs where we‚Äôve been for the last thirty years. The year that we moved in Mitra made me swear an oath. She made me promise that I would die before her, because she couldn‚Äôt stand the thought of me being with another woman. Maziar and his wife were doing their medical residency at the time, so most nights we were on our own. Because of Mitra‚Äôs hand injury, much of the childcare fell to me. I‚Äôd be up all night with one baby in each arm: this one needs a bottle, that one needs a diaper change. When the boys grew a bit older Mitra took over the clothing decisions. She was determined for them to have matching bathrobes. She couldn‚Äôt find the exact ones she wanted in America, so she ordered fancy bathrobes from Europe. I was responsible for the physical activities: the wrestling, the hiking, the fishing. In our backyard we built a small garden, and in their quieter moments they would help me tend it. But my most important job was teaching them our language. The vessel of our culture. I wanted to lead them to the source of the spring, so that they could read the words our writers have written. And sing the songs our singers have sung. The Persian alphabet can be difficult, so I didn‚Äôt start with letters. I started with words. I chose three hundred words. Simple words, words that everyone should know: ùòîùò¶ùò©ùò≥. Love. ùòôùò¢ùò¥ùòµùò™. Truth. ùòïùò¶ùò¶ùò¨ùò™. Goodness. While we were working in the garden, I‚Äôd say them over and over. It didn‚Äôt matter to me if anyone was listening or paying attention. All that mattered was that the words were being spoken. Every time we took a long trip in the car, I‚Äôd prompt them with the same question: What are the two things that God has given everyone? ùòëùò¢ùò¢ùòØ and ùòíùò©ùò¶ùò≥ùò¢ùò•. Soul and Wisdom.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a miracle I‚Äôm even here. My father went through World War II: the Normandy Invasion, Omaha Beach. So for him to survive all that, and live long enough to become my father‚Äîit‚Äôs a miraculous thing. He died before I was eight years old. But it was enough time to experience him deeply. I was very loved, very welcomed, very cared for: my parents were thrilled I was their child. When I was younger I traveled quite a bit. Not every place, but a lot of places: Greece, Turkey, Alaska. And this wasn‚Äôt just going on tours. It was real, vagabond stuff: no reservations, no plans. Just deeply experiencing another culture and another place. I‚Äôve gotten to do every kind of work, from agricultural labor to factory work. For twenty years I was a social worker with seniors. But I can‚Äôt even call that a job, it was a service. I got to take care of people: bring them meals, help with housekeeping. It was an absolute calling. I was a workaholic. And now that I‚Äôm retired‚Äî I‚Äôm a play-aholic. There‚Äôs nonstop free music in New York. I come to this park to listen to jazz piano. I go to Juilliard to listen to student recitals. There‚Äôs going to be a Dixieland ragtime ensemble near Macy‚Äôs. I mean, it‚Äôs endless. I‚Äôm just grateful for good health to enjoy it all. So many people wake up in pain. But I have my health, and I have a home. I mean, it‚Äôs not a home. But I have a place. A safe place to rent. It‚Äôs just been a blessed, beautiful life. The perfect life for me. I found it very, very rich. Very deep. And I think all of it was a blessing. All of it, miracles and blessings.‚Äù

caption: (54/54) ‚ÄúI wish I could see it again. Just one more time. I wouldn‚Äôt need long. I‚Äôd spend a day in Tehran. I‚Äôd visit Persepolis, to see the ruins. I‚Äôd go to Nahavand, to see my people. To meet their children. And the children of their children. And then I‚Äôd go to his tomb. He was buried in his garden. And to stand there one more time, where he tended his trees. Where he sowed his seeds. Seven verses a day. I‚Äôd say them quietly in my head, I wouldn‚Äôt want to disturb the peace. But something happens, I can‚Äôt help it. I feel the heat. I feel the pressure. It‚Äôs like a sword pierces my body and I have to let it out: ùòôùò¢ùò¨ùò©ùò¥ùò© ùò≥ùò∞ùò¢ùò≥ùò¶ùò• ùò£ùò¶ùòØùò¶ùò¢ùòµùò© ùòôùò∞ùò¥ùòµùò¢ùòÆ! The thunder of hooves, the spark of swords, the clash of axes, the single arrow spinning through the air. ùòûùò©ùò∞ ùò¢ùò≥ùò¶ ùòµùò©ùò¶ùò¥ùò¶ ùòóùò¶ùò≥ùò¥ùò™ùò¢ùòØùò¥? Rumi, Saadi, Hafez, Khayyam, Ferdowsi. Not even a lion! Not even a lion could stand against them! Our kings. Our queens. Our castles. Our battles. Our banquets. Our songs and celebrations. Our culture. Our wisdom. Our choices. Our story. And our words. All of our words. Words of mothers, words of fathers, words that teach, words that fly, words that cut, words that heal, words laughed, words sung, words wept, words prayed, words whispered in a moonlit garden, words of sin, words kissed, words sighed, words spoken from one knee. ùòîùò¶ùò©ùò≥. Words forgotten. Words remembered again. Words written on a page. Words etched on the face of a tomb. ùòëùò¢ùò¢ùòØ. ùòíùò©ùò¶ùò≥ùò¢ùò•. A castle of words! That no wind or rain will destroy! Who we were. Who we were! But also, who we wanted to be. We begin in darkness. A siren screams. A knight appears. A knight with the heart of a lion. A knight with a voice to make, the hardened hearts of warriors quake. A knight who rode out to face the enemy alone, and she roared. She roared! She roared at the enemy lines! Here! Here is your champion! Her wisdom, her soul, her voice, her faith, her power, her heart, her passion, her sin, her choice, her life, her fight, her fire, her fury, her justice! And her hair. Hair like a waterfall. Hair like silk. Hair like night. Hair worthy of a crown. ùòàùòªùò¢ùò•ùò™. All of Iran, in a single poem.‚Äù

caption: (35/54) ‚ÄúEvery morning we woke to the sound of shots coming from the prison near our house. The executions were always held at dawn. When the newspaper arrived later that morning, it would show the names and photographs of the dead. An atmosphere of fear began to spread across the country. It wasn‚Äôt just the killings. It was the news of the killings, the manner of the killings. They were random. They followed no law. Revolutionary tribunals were formed to deal with enemies of the regime, but there was no due process. Sometimes there wouldn‚Äôt even be a trial. Khomeini appointed an executioner as one of the judges. A bus would arrive at his court. He‚Äôd let one person pass, then hold the next. When the entire bus had been emptied‚Äîthe people who were held back would be executed. The story spread across the country. When violence is random, when it is undeserved, when there is no ùò•ùò¢ùò¢ùò•, everyone begins to think: I could be next. And that‚Äôs exactly what the regime wanted. People grew silent. They would only speak their mind inside their homes. One month after the revolution, there was the first protest against the regime. It happened on International Women‚Äôs Day. Thousands of women took to the streets to protest the mandatory hijab. They called for the freedom to choose. ùòàùòªùò¢ùò•ùò™. They screamed their slogans in the streets. But their words were never heard. The regime had already taken over the media, and the protests weren‚Äôt mentioned anywhere. Then came Khomeini‚Äôs followers. They fell on the women like savages, beating them with batons. Calling them ‚Äòwhores‚Äô and ‚Äòsluts.‚Äô Bystanders looked on in fear. Nobody tried to defend them. No one spoke a word. There was silence.‚Äù

caption: (37/54) ‚ÄúThe meeting was held in the office of the former speaker of parliament. He‚Äôd been executed four weeks earlier. It was an office I‚Äôd been to many times before. But everything beautiful had been removed: the paintings, the carpets, the furniture. In the center of the room was a single table, and at its head sat one of the leaders of the Revolutionary Council. It was the body ultimately responsible for deciding the fate of the regime‚Äôs enemies. My colleague groveled. He read a prepared statement. He thanked the man for his wisdom. He thanked him for allowing us to keep our salaries. Then when he finished his remarks, he motioned to me and said: ‚ÄòMy colleague would like to say something.‚Äô I was caught by surprise. I had nothing prepared. I could have just thanked the man. But when an injustice has been committed, I must speak. It‚Äôs part of my code. It‚Äôs something I hold as dear as my own spirit. Because if we don‚Äôt live our ideals‚Äîthen they don‚Äôt exist. ùòãùò¢ùò¢ùò•. ùòïùò¶ùò¶ùò¨ùò™. ùòôùò¢ùò¥ùòµùò™. Justice, Goodness, Truth. They depend on us. We are the ones who must make them real. They only exist when we are living them. Truth is not some abstract concept. Truth is something you say. Truth is something you do. No matter how great the fear, you must follow your code. You must stay true to your ideals. Because if you do not, that fear will stay with you. It will break you. Every day it will remind you: you weren‚Äôt who you thought you were. And I‚Äôm not ready to lose the rest of my life to a single moment. There was a burnt match lying on the floor next to my foot. I picked it up off the ground. I looked the man in the eye, and I told him: ‚ÄòMaybe you should be thanking us, for not allowing this injustice.‚Äô Then I held the burnt match in front of my face. ‚ÄòEven if you‚Äôd asked,‚Äô I told him. ‚ÄòI wouldn‚Äôt have given you this burnt match.‚Äô‚Äù

caption: (36/54) ‚ÄúThe religious fanatics were less than ten percent, but you couldn‚Äôt tell them apart. They looked like us. They spoke the same language. They did what no invader had been able to do for three thousand years‚Äîerase our nation, our culture, our connection to the past. But they did it from the inside. In the beginning things were relaxed. The first Prime Minister was a pious Muslim, but he was an educated man. A thoughtful man. Mitra attended an event where he was speaking, and his wife wasn‚Äôt even wearing a hijab. But the clerics slowly worked their way into government. And the more they got power, the more the environment became closed. Cinemas were shut down. Music was banned from television. The poetry of Farrokhzad was banned. It‚Äôs not that Mitra promoted Khomeini, but she defended him. She‚Äôd say that the king wasn‚Äôt innocent either. She said that she liked the hijab. She felt that it was a symbol of modesty, and respect for tradition. At the time I was more religious than Mitra. But I couldn‚Äôt make her understand: the problem isn‚Äôt Islam. There is nothing wrong with hijab. But there must be ùò¢ùòªùò¢ùò•ùò™. There must be the freedom to choose. I think Mitra only took the other side because she wanted to discourage me from speaking out. She wanted to keep me safe. Dr. Ameli had already gone into hiding. The regime was looking for any reason to go after people. They‚Äôd sent agents to Nahavand looking for evidence of corruption, but they could not find a thing. One day Khomeini ordered every member of parliament to pay back their salaries. But my former colleagues in the opposition petitioned for an exemption. They argued that we‚Äôd been critical of the king‚Äôs policies, and at the last minute an exemption was granted. One of my colleagues requested a meeting with a leader of the Revolutionary Council. He wanted to express his gratitude, and he asked me to come along for support. I didn‚Äôt want to do it. I didn‚Äôt feel any gratitude at all. I hadn‚Äôt done anything wrong. It would have been unjust to take my salary. But he begged me to come. And he promised that I would not need to speak.‚Äù

caption: (42/54) ‚ÄúAt dawn we woke to the sound of shots. First the machine gun fire, then the single shots. That morning I counted more than ever before: twenty-one. When the newspaper arrived that morning, I ran my finger down the list until I found his name. It has always been my belief, that if one of us could have survived, it should have been him. He could have united people. His entire life, all his thoughts, all his words, led back to one thing: our common destiny. When you only fight for one lane, one party, one policy-- all you see is conflict. Unity is so elusive. There is only one thing we all share: Iran. And nobody knew Iran more-- nobody loved Iran more-- than Dr. Ameli. We‚Äôd later learn his last words were: ‚ÄòDo not think of me, think of Iran.‚Äô He was so brilliant. He could have earned all the money in the world. But that‚Äôs not where he stored his treasures. He chose to have less, so he could do more. And that is the rarest kind of person. There should be a statue of him in the center of Tehran. But nobody heard the story of his life. Nobody heard the story of his death. It was a seed that didn‚Äôt fall into soil. It was too dangerous to even hold a memorial service. We couldn‚Äôt grieve. We couldn‚Äôt gather together to share our memories. Our only way to honor him was to keep working, to keep resisting in whatever small way we could. We found an empty conference hall, a place so isolated that no one could hear our voices. And we‚Äôd hold meetings late at night. We‚Äôd bring in singers with beautiful voices, and they‚Äôd sing songs. Songs about loving Iran. And as people were leaving we‚Äôd hand out cassettes with the speeches of Dr. Ameli. At the very least we could spread his words. On the cover of the cassette we put a picture of his face, next to The Lion and The Sun. They‚Äôre two of the oldest symbols of Iran. The sun, the source of all light. And the lion. The lion is the most powerful animal in Iran. It‚Äôs loyal. It would do anything for its tribe. And it doesn‚Äôt run from anything. The lion is not the largest animal, but its power doesn‚Äôt come from its size. It comes from its heart. Its courage. Its soul. Its ùòØùò™ùò≥ùò∞ùò∞.‚Äù

caption: (38/54) ‚ÄúI could not find it anywhere. The Iran of Shahnameh. The Iran of Cyrus The Great. The Iran of Rumi, Hafez, Saadi, Khayyam. The Iran of our mothers and fathers. The Iran that I had loved since I was a little boy‚Äîit was no use to them. They didn‚Äôt care about our culture, our history, our ideals. One day Khomeini gave a speech saying that nationalism was against Islam. He said that we should be a nation of Muslims, not a nation of Iranians. The Lion and the Sun were removed from our flag, two of the oldest symbols of Iran. They were replaced by Arabic writing. Our institutions were dismantled one-by-one, until the only things left of the republic and constitution were their names. They became empty boxes that no one knew what was inside. Three months after the revolution I took one final trip to Nahavand. These were the people who trusted me most. Nobody could say that I‚Äôd ever wronged them. I wanted to speak with them freely, and share my thoughts. I wanted to see if they grieved along with me. Normally the moment that my car pulled into town, the news would spread like wildfire. People would gather at the house of my father. It had a very large salon, and people would come and go as they pleased. They‚Äôd come in excited, passionate, sometimes angry. They‚Äôd be critical. They‚Äôd debate me. Everyone had something to say. But this time only a small crowd gathered. And I was the only one who spoke. I shared all of my concerns: that we were losing our ideals. We were losing ùòãùò¢ùò¢ùò•. We were losing ùòïùò¶ùò¶ùò¨ùò™. We were losing ùòôùò¢ùò¥ùòµùò™. We were losing ùòàùòªùò¢ùò•ùò™. But everyone just listened in silence. They knew my words were true. They knew better than me. But it was fear. They were silenced by fear. There is a famous parable about a caravan of one hundred merchants crossing the desert. Their camels are loaded down with riches. In the night they are overtaken by two bandits, and robbed of everything. Afterwards they are asked: ‚ÄòHow could it possibly happen? There were one hundred of you, but only two of them.‚Äô They replied: ‚ÄòYes. But those two were together. And we were alone.‚Äù

caption: (44/54) ‚ÄúOn my final morning in Iran I woke with the sun. I knelt to the ground and prayed. It was a six mile walk to the border. The road climbed through the mountains, the same mountains that ran through Nahavand. But in Nahavand the trees were green. Here there was no life. Ferdowsi once wrote: ‚ÄòYou cannot escape what is written.‚Äô I‚Äôve always hated that quote. There‚Äôs always a choice to be made. Just do the next right thing. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôve always believed. Do the next right thing, say the next true thing, and a path will open up. A way will appear. I thought that we could get there. I thought that we, as a people, were going to get there. Every day we would take a step closer: more jobs, more hospitals, more schools. If only we kept choosing the next right thing, we could get there. We could build a new Iran around us. In the end light would win, as Ferdowsi writes: ‚ÄòThe universe bends toward goodness.‚Äô But you must never underestimate the forces of darkness. They can be victorious for a long time. Years. Decades. Lifetimes. Ferdowsi worked for thirty-three years. Seven verses a day. In the name of the God of Soul and Wisdom. But when he finished no one cared. Iran had been invaded once again, this time by the Turks. No one took the time to read his words. He died a broken man. Nobody heard the story of his life. Nobody heard the story of his death. He wasn‚Äôt even given a proper burial. The local cleric wouldn‚Äôt allow him to be buried in an Islamic cemetery, so they buried him in his garden. But he died with hope. Because he knew. He knew that no matter how deep they are buried, some words have wings. At the end of Shahnameh, Ferdowsi wrote: ‚ÄúI shall not die. These seeds I‚Äôve sown will save my name and memory from the grave.‚Äù

caption: (39/54) ‚ÄúIt would have been suicide to fight. There were no courts to petition. No laws to challenge. The only weapon that we had left were our words. I joined together with five colleagues from the Pan-Iranist party, and we formed an underground journal. We met daily in an abandoned office. We wrote with pen and paper, and when each issue was finished it would be secretly printed by a friend that worked at a publishing house. I wrote under the name of Rahdmard. It was the same name Mitra and I would later give to our fourth child, who was born severely disabled. It means a man who is noble. A man who is morally upright. It‚Äôs what I wanted for him, and it‚Äôs what I wanted for myself as well. In my articles I never attacked the regime directly. I didn‚Äôt mention the executions. I never named any names. Instead I wrote about ideals and principles. ùòãùò¢ùò¢ùò•. ùòôùò¢ùò¥ùòµùò™. ùòàùòªùò¢ùò•ùò™. I said: ‚ÄòLet us not lose ourselves. Let us not descend back into darkness.‚Äô We had no idea if our words were being read. Each issue would only be one thousand copies, and we‚Äôd only pass them out amongst our friends. But we were like a dying person who was desperate to live. If we wanted to survive, these were the breaths we had to take. Just being together gave us hope. Darkness was pressing in all around us. But coming together for a single purpose, a single goal‚Äîit gave our hearts energy. Each day we‚Äôd share the news we‚Äôd seen and heard. We talked about what we could do, how we could help. One of the members had been sheltering Dr. Ameli at his house. He‚Äôd been staying there since the first days of the revolution. But after several weeks he began to miss his wife and family. So he decided to leave the safehouse. He knew that he was innocent, so he took a chance. He went back home. And that‚Äôs where they grabbed him.‚Äù

caption: (34/54) ‚ÄúThe revolution officially ended on February 11th, 1979. The military announced that they would no longer resist, and Khomeini‚Äôs forces took control of the weapons. That morning a bullet came through our window and landed in the wall above our bed. The country became like a house in an earthquake. Everything was scattered and there was nowhere to hide. The streets were barricaded with big bags of sand. Behind them were men holding automatic weapons. The executions began on the roof of the same school building where we had met. First the generals were executed. A few days later it was the Prime Minister. Then several powerful members of parliament. Khomeini would walk out afterward to inspect the bodies. Our house was next to the prison where former members of the king‚Äôs government were being held. Every morning we‚Äôd wake to the sound of the firing squads. Gordafarid was ten years old at the time. She was scared by all the gunfire, so at night I‚Äôd read to her the story of her namesake: Gordafarid from Shahnameh. When the men refused to fight, Gordafarid tied her hair beneath her helmet. She loaded an arrow into her bow. And she rode out from the castle to face the enemy alone. She stopped just short of the enemy lines, and she roared. She roared like thunder! ‚ÄòWhere are your champions? Who would dare to fight me?‚Äô Only the enemy commander had the nerve to answer her challenge. With fury they fought. The battle burned, the rain of arrows, the spark of swords. Neither champion could strike a fatal blow. Then in the heat of the battle Gordafarid‚Äôs helmet was knocked to the ground. Her face shone like the moon. And her hair, her hair was worthy of a crown. The commander was stunned. A woman! It was a woman! He turned to his men, and screamed: ‚ÄòIf the Iranians have women such as these, who would dare? Who would dare to face them?‚Äù

caption: (45/54) A jar of soil. That‚Äôs all I have left of my home. It‚Äôs good soil. A guidebook once called Nahavand ‚Äòa piece of heaven, fallen to earth.‚Äô But there‚Äôs blood in the soil too. There have been more wars on Iran‚Äôs soil than any other country. We‚Äôve had more battles, more bloodshed, more defeats than any other people. And this has been one of the worst of them. The people who stayed in Iran tried their best. But one by one they fell: anyone who stepped out, anyone who spoke up, anyone who said: ‚ÄòThis is not working for us.‚Äô They were silenced. It was a savage violence. A violence from fourteen hundred years ago. From the moment of those very first executions on the roof of the school, there has been no coherence. No ùò•ùò¢ùò¢ùò•. The smallest act could lead to death: a blog post, a sign at a protest, a few strands of hair showing beneath a headscarf. The regime needs fear to stay in control. And for fear to spread, the violence must be random. So that everyone thinks: ‚ÄòI could be next. It could happen to me.‚Äô They‚Äôve turned the country into a dark forest. When there is light, when there is law, when there is ùò•ùò¢ùò¢ùò•, you know where danger comes from. You can keep away from it. But in the dark danger can come from anywhere, at any time. Parvaneh stayed. The young woman from ùòïùò™ùò≥ùò∞ùò∞. The one with the strongest voice. She tried to work for change within the country. In an interview she told a reporter: ‚ÄòIranians abroad can provide spiritual support, but the front must emerge from within Iran.‚Äô She kept writing. She kept speaking out. She kept fighting for political freedom. Only now she was fighting for one-tenth the freedoms that she had before. One night the intelligence services broke into her home. They stabbed her to death, alongside her husband. Dariush was a tall man, much bigger than Parvaneh. But they stabbed her twice as many times. Either they hated her twice as much, or she fought them twice as hard.‚Äù

caption: (43/54) ‚ÄúThirty years earlier we‚Äôd sworn an oath, to give our lives for Iran. I considered it. There was one parliamentarian who fled to the mountains and died fighting. Even with one eye, I was still a good shot. I could have made a stand. But if I gave my life, it would have to be in exchange for something. Thousands of people were dying at the time, and nothing was changing. The clerics only grew more powerful. The same slogans were being chanted in the streets. Our freedoms continued to be taken away. And then there was Mitra and the children. I couldn‚Äôt leave them behind. But with each week came more bad news: another colleague killed, another one arrested. My friends started encouraging me to leave the country, but I wouldn‚Äôt consider it. I had promised myself when I came home from Germany that I‚Äôd never leave Iran again. But even if I had wanted to, it wasn‚Äôt possible. I didn‚Äôt have a passport. I was on a list of people who were not allowed to leave the country. One afternoon we received a visit from a former colleague. He sat Mitra and I down in the living room, and he told us that he‚Äôd discovered a way to leave Iran through the Turkish border. There was a powerful family there that was known to oppose the regime. He said that the checkpoints weren‚Äôt stopping cars with families. So if Mitra rode to the border with me, I‚Äôd be able to walk the rest of the way on foot. He turned to Mitra, and said: ‚ÄòThis is his final chance. If he is killed, never say that his friends abandoned him. We‚Äôve done everything we can to convince him, so now it‚Äôs up to you.‚Äô When he was finished, Mitra turned to me and said: ‚ÄòYou must go.‚Äô And Mitra‚Äôs word is law. We set out early in the morning. It was an eight-hour drive to the Turkish border. The entire ride was spent in silence. She kept her emotions hidden. I was a tsunami of tears. We kissed goodbye in Salmas. There was a statue of Ferdowsi in the main square.‚Äù

caption: (40/54) ‚ÄúEvery morning we awoke to the sound of shots. The executions would begin with a volley of machine gun fire. Then there‚Äôd be a round of single shots, to make sure the prisoners were dead. I‚Äôd lay in bed and count them. When the newspaper arrived later that morning, I‚Äôd search for his name among the killed. I was so angry with him. He‚Äôd been so careless. On the day he decided to leave the safehouse, he had even made a joke. He‚Äôd said: ‚ÄòIf they arrest me, we‚Äôll all go to court and have a good laugh.‚Äô He knew that he‚Äôd done nothing wrong. His entire career, he had been the model of integrity. He thought that his innocence would be enough. He thought: ‚ÄòWhat is true, will be true for everyone.‚Äô But in this system there was no ùò≥ùò¢ùò¥ùòµùò™. There was no ùò•ùò¢ùò¢ùò•. It was one set of rules for believers, and another set of rules for nonbelievers. I watched some of the show trials on television, to see if I could find him. There were no lawyers, no witnesses, nothing. Just a few people with beards. They‚Äôd hand down vague sentences like ‚ÄòCrimes against God,‚Äô which carried a sentence of death. We tried everything. We looked everywhere, we called everyone, but nobody knew where they‚Äôd taken him. Finally we were able to arrange a meeting with one of Iran‚Äôs highest ranking religious figures, Ayatollah Shariatmadari.  We visited him at his house and pleaded with him to intercede. We told him: an innocent man has been arrested, one of the most honest men in all of Iran. There must be some justice. There must be some consideration of the truth. The Ayatollah was a good man. A man with ùòØùò¶ùò¶ùò¨ùò™. He was a man of faith, rather than a religious man. He listened with concern; we could see the compassion in his eyes. But there was nothing he could do. He‚Äôd already fallen out of favor with Khomeini; and a few months later he‚Äôd be arrested himself. After that there was no hope.‚Äù

caption: (41/54) ‚ÄúMitra couldn‚Äôt sleep without me. On the nights when I came home late, I‚Äôd always find her awake listening to tapes. We still read poetry together. Even in the midst of the chaos, even on the darkest nights, even if only for twenty minutes. It was my greatest comfort. The time when I felt most at peace. One of the most famous love stories in all of Shahnameh is the tale of Bijan and Manijeh. It‚Äôs a special story. Because it‚Äôs the one time in Shahnameh when Ferdowsi reveals a glimpse of his own life. He writes in the chapter‚Äôs opening that he has fallen into a great depression. He describes a night so dark that no birds sing. He calls for his wife to join him, and she brings him a candle. She offers to tell him a story, and Ferdowsi agrees to weave it into verse. She tells him the story of Bijan and Manijeh. Bijan is a champion of Iran. Manijeh is the daughter of an enemy king. By chance they meet in the forest, and Manijeh mistakes Bijan for an angel. She falls in love at first sight. She smuggles him back to her palace, and they spend several nights in each other‚Äôs arms. Until their love is discovered by the king. He grows so angry that he cries tears of blood. He banishes Manijeh from the palace. And he sentences Bijan to a fate worse than death. Total darkness. Bijan is chained to the bottom of the deepest pit, and a stone is rolled over the entrance. But Manijeh will not allow him to die. She roams the countryside, begging for food. She digs a hole beneath the stone, just large enough to fit her hand. And she keeps Bijan alive. One handful at a time.‚Äù

caption: (26/54) ‚ÄúMitra was the oldest in her class, but all the younger students loved her. She knew all the latest in culture: the movies, the magazines, the trends. Every night when I came home she‚Äôd always be up listening to tapes. The seventies were a golden age of music in Iran: Googoosh, Delkash, Marzieh, Aslani, Hayedeh, Shajarian. And Mitra had many of their songs memorized. She was a great student. During the second year of her program she was chosen to study under one of Iran‚Äôs top Shahnameh professors. It was the closest she ever came to understanding me. One day in class the professor told her that every society needs a few idealists, because they‚Äôre the ones who move society forward. Often I would help with her homework, and it helped me view Shahnameh from a more academic perspective. Ferdowsi uses the mythic kings as placeholders for periods in Iran‚Äôs history. When he writes that Jamshid ruled for seven hundred years, he means that it was a time of great freedom and culture in Iran. But when Jamshid loses touch with the people, a period of terror and oppression follows. The throne is taken over by the Serpent King Zahak. In Shahnameh Zahak is the embodiment of darkness. He cares only for his own power. Two giant snakes grow out of his shoulders. The devil promises Zahak that he will stay in power, as long as he feeds the snakes with the brains of young Iranians. It had to be the brains of the young. Because young people are the ones with energy. They‚Äôre the ones with courage. They‚Äôre the ones that can overthrow the regime. One day twenty students at Mitra‚Äôs school entered the cafeteria wearing masks, and began to forcibly separate men and women. They physically assaulted any women who were wearing make-up or Western clothing. On the way out they scattered pamphlets on the floor, warning that all women should adhere to Islamic guidelines‚Äîor there will be consequences. An atmosphere of fear began to spread across the campus. Mitra began wearing a hijab to school. She chose a beautiful white one, made of silk.‚Äù
