caption: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm starting to feel calmer about it. People separate all the time, right? Even with children; they make it work. I‚Äôm just frustrated that it was thirteen years of my life. He‚Äôs a great father. But it was thirteen years of not being loved the way I deserve. Or want, right? Or need, even. I was just too scared of doing it alone. Now the journey‚Äôs come to an end, and it‚Äôs like: ‚ÄòWow, I‚Äôm really not who I used to be.‚Äô I was so spontaneous, even with something as simple as driving. I used to drive all the time. I‚Äôd drive all night just to spend a day at the beach. But after we started a family, my husband drove. It was just our flow. Then it became a crutch. Then it got to the point where I couldn‚Äôt do it anymore, especially with my kids in the car. I was too scared. I‚Äôd lost that part of myself. Right before my 40th birthday we got in a big fight. It wasn‚Äôt the end; but it was close to the end. That night I bought myself a birthday present: one ticket to a resort in the Dominican Republic. Just one ticket. He‚Äôd up and leave no problem; especially if it‚Äôs work-related, right? So why not me? But right after I booked the ticket, I got so scared. I almost cancelled. But my sister was insistent. She‚Äôs a mother too; she said: ‚ÄòStephanie, you‚Äôve got to go. And don‚Äôt you dare take someone with you.‚Äô It was only three nights. But when I say I smiled the whole trip, I mean it. I met so many other solo travelers. There was this old Russian woman; we saw each other everywhere. She‚Äôd float by me in the water. We took salsa classes together. She didn‚Äôt speak English, but every time she saw me she‚Äôd smile so big, like: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs you. You‚Äôre that girl.‚Äô A few days after I came home, I was alone with the girls. My older daughter had a birthday party deep in Queens. Normally I‚Äôd have said no. Two hours on the subway; it was just too much. But I said: ‚ÄòYou know what? We‚Äôre doing it.‚Äô I booked a Zipcar. I hadn‚Äôt driven in years. I was panicking the whole time. My twelve-year-old was navigating, both of them were laughing at me. All of us were laughing the entire way. But we made it, didn‚Äôt we? When we got there I said: ‚ÄòWell girls, we can drive to Queens. I guess we can drive anywhere.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúWhen he was born I took him see his grandfather. I brought him to the construction site where he worked, so they could meet. But my dad didn‚Äôt even make an effort. And when he did come home he was always screaming, always hitting. For every little thing: if we didn‚Äôt brush our teeth, if we didn‚Äôt help out enough around the house. He treated my mom bad too. I tried to stop it. When I got older people would have to physically separate us. The anger is in me too. It comes from the inside. I‚Äôll start to get mad, and suddenly it‚Äôs all over me. But whenever that starts to happen, I think: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm not going to be him. I‚Äôm not going to be him.‚Äô I‚Äôll walk away and calm down. Then I‚Äôll come back and apologize. I‚Äôll say: ‚ÄòWhat you did was wrong. But it was also wrong for me to speak that way. And I promise not to be like that again.‚Äô I try to show him respect. Even though he‚Äôs a kid, he deserves the same respect as any person‚Äî even more, actually. Because an old person knows what‚Äôs going on, and he doesn‚Äôt. I always say goodnight with a kiss. caption: ‚ÄúI was making adults cry, with my voice. At the age of six. Everyone recognized my talent. And that‚Äôs when I began to tell myself a story: ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre just as good as anyone else, or even better. You deserve everything you want.‚Äô It was a bit egotistical. But it was the story I needed back then. I needed a story to make me feel enthusiastic, to make me fight. I came to the city at the age of 22; it was a perfect time to be in the New York City jazz scene. I got to sing on stage with Dizzy Gillespie, Joe Williams, Betty Carter. I ended up falling in love with another jazz singer. We became a duet, had some success, raised our children on the road. But then we fell apart, and so did our careers. I was never able to build it back to what it had been. Now I‚Äôm watching my kids succeed more than me. It makes me feel like I did my job as a mother: I was able to pass down everything I know. But it can be painful, too. Because they‚Äôre doing everything I desired most: they‚Äôre on stage, sharing their talents, being recognized. There‚Äôs a voice inside me that says: ‚ÄòYou deserve that too. There‚Äôs still time. You can still do that.‚Äô But that‚Äôs not the story I need to tell myself anymore. I don‚Äôt need a story to help me fight. I need a story to help me feel good in the moment. There‚Äôs this more mature part of me that says: Relax. You did a good job. You did a lot of stuff. The earth life only offers so many types of experiences. And I got to play so many parts: I got to be a singer, yes. But also the faithful daughter, the free-spirited girl who went off to explore the world, the pot-smoking hippie, the wild woman, the fool, the lover, the wife, the scorned woman, and the giving mother. Now I feel like I‚Äôm getting back to the Kim I was when I was five, before the story began: joking around, singing to my cat, singing to people on the street. Being happy for everyone else. Not worrying about getting ahead. Believing everything is going to work out. And that I‚Äôm exactly where I was always supposed to be.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúMy grandmother got us out of foster care, piece by piece. At one point there were like fifteen kids in her home: all my siblings, all my cousins. She worked all the time, sewing linings into hats for Jewish men. There was a room in the basement with four sewing machines, and everyone had to do their part. It was tough love. But she kept us together. My mother never came to visit, not even once. Not even on weekends. And I was a curious kid, so that killed me: never knowing why. But every morning I got to wake up with my siblings and my cousins, and I was thankful for that. That was beautiful. And our grandmother gave us that. One morning when I was twelve she sat me down, and said: ‚ÄòYour mother wants you back, but you‚Äôre welcome to stay.‚Äô She gave me that choice. And I decided to move in with my mother. By that time she‚Äôd gotten clean. And she showed me love. Way more love. Way more. Not in the way of: I‚Äôm going to give you a hug, or a kiss. But listening. Like, I‚Äôm listening to you. My grandmother was stretched too thin for one-on-one. So I‚Äôd never felt heard as a child. But my mother would take me on these long walks. She‚Äôd let me talk and talk. She‚Äôd be my ear. She taught me that I have a personality. I never knew I had a personality. It was always just wake up and do what everyone else does. My mother showed me how to be happy. She was so joyful. She wore the brightest clothes. She was like a rainbow in a person, and she became my best friend. She died of a heart attack when I was fifteen; she died in my arms. And part of me is always going to feel broken because of that. That‚Äôs the part I don‚Äôt show my kids, you know. The part that still feels alone. But we had three years together. And during that time she answered all my questions; that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm most thankful for. She was an open book. She told me her trauma, her story. How she met my father. How she was introduced to a lifestyle that she just didn‚Äôt know about. How she got so addicted, and how she never wanted me to see her like that. Not even once. Now I‚Äôll never have to wonder. She gave me the gift of knowing. Knowing why she did what she did. But mainly, knowing what having a mom feels like.‚Äù

caption: ‚ÄúI used to say: ‚ÄòI like to watch TikTok, or YouTube.‚Äô But I don‚Äôt really like to describe myself that way anymore. Because if you think about it, that‚Äôs not really something you do. It‚Äôs just something that pulls you in. It made me feel connected. Like, I know this person. But I really didn‚Äôt know them at all. And I‚Äôd sit at home getting sucked into this endless void of whatever I was watching. Windows closed, AC on. My dad would say: ‚ÄòGo outside and do something, it builds character.‚Äô Most of the time he‚Äôd only say it because he wanted me to take out the trash, or go on an errand with him. So for a long time I didn‚Äôt think it meant anything. But it really does, if you think about it. Because every time you do something, it adds to who you are. You learn from life. caption: ‚ÄòMy downfall was when I first got a Kindle. I went straight to the self-published stuff the authors were selling for nothing. A lot of it was Romance. I read stuff my eleven-year-old self should not have been reading. But my favorite was called The ABCs of Kissing Boys. I read it multiple times. It‚Äôs about a girl who‚Äôs never been kissed. She falls in love with the next-door neighbor. She‚Äôd grown up with him. But one day she looked up, and he was different. And he was there. It gave me hope. I‚Äôd never been one who was sought after. I‚Äôd get these big, all-encompassing crushes. And they‚Äôd always just devastate me. But when I read these books, it was like: I can be her. It can happen. I fell in love with Romance. I even wrote my college thesis on it. There are a few rules every Romance must follow. Rule number one: it has to be about the romance. The book could be set in outer space. But it‚Äôs not about space exploration. It‚Äôs about two people who fall in love. Toward the end there will always be some sort of fight, or miscommunication. That‚Äôs the thrill of it. But it‚Äôs also the hardest part to do successfully. Because in the back of their mind, the reader knows. Rule number two: every Romance has a happy ending. Right now I‚Äôm still in my first act. A small-town girl moves to New York. She hasn‚Äôt found her dream job yet at a Romance publisher. But she‚Äôs working at an academic publisher, so she‚Äôs in the solar system. On weekends she works at a bookstore called Books Are Magic. Maybe one day, somebody will walk in. Boy, girl, doesn‚Äôt matter. They‚Äôll buy her favorite book. Then they‚Äôll keep coming back to buy the books she recommends. She‚Äôll become the first person they text whenever they want to chat.
